title: Can Baby Universe Absorption Explain Dark Energy?
authors: Varun Muralidharan and James M. Cline
abstract:
It has been proposed that the accelerated expansion of the universe can be
explained by the merging of our universe with baby universes, resulting in dark
energy with a phantom-like equation of state. However, the evidence in favor of
it did not include the full set of cosmological observables. Here we examine
the implications of this model for both early and late universe cosmology using
data from Planck collaboration, DESI 2024 and other experiments. We find that
the pure baby universe model gives a poor fit to current data. Extending it to
include a contribution from the cosmological constant, we find two allowed
regions of parameter space: one close to $\Lambda$CDM, and another with
$\Lambda <0$ plus the exotic dark energy component. The two regions can be
significantly favored over $\Lambda$CDM, depending on the choice of supernova
datasets, and they can ameliorate the Hubble tension to the level of $2\sigma$,
depending on the supernova dataset. The model with $\Lambda<0$ features an
equation of state $w(a)$ with a pole singularity at early times.
